label: Finn the Finder
narrative: Finders may intentionally or unintentionally discover vulnerabilities in software. They are the hackers, security researchers, academics, bug bounty hunters, and concerned software enthusiasts.

goals: Wants to discover vulnerabilities before any threat actors do.
Looks for recognition and credit (or monetary rewards) for the effort of discovering complex and high severity issues to grow their career and reputation.
dislikes: Projects that do now have well published public vulnerability disclosure policies.
Developers, vendors, and project maintainers who are not responsive to disclosed findings.
Vulnerabilities that are discovered and later exploited in the wild.

design: Vulnerability disclosure process that is clear, concise, and easy to follow for both novices and experts.
product: Beginner-friendly contribution pathways, enhanced documentation, and mentorship.

Track Mean Time to Remediate (MTTR) for found vulnerabilities and disclose in scorecards. This can help consumers make automated decisions using risk metrics (scorecard) to undersatnd projects that are responsive.
education: Tech talks, working groups, and policy summits can be effective educational opportunities.
If not a regular contributor, may be unaware of vulnerability disclosure processes or procedures to discreetly connect finders with project maintainers. Push educational resources.

Share case studies like lessons learned from not following disclosure processes. Address concerns about open vulnerabilities that are disclosed but not quickly closed/resolved by maintainers/projects.
communications: Clear enterprise-facing communication on tool adoption and compliance is helpful.
Software security development courses should have messaging for what to do if a vulnerability is dislosed.
Provide filters for communication so that there is a high signal to noise ratio to ensure valuable critical information is seen while suppressing some engagement opportunities.
sales: Organize a Security Incident Response Team (SIRT) to be in place and provide support to projects when high profile vulnerabilities are discovered to offset any lack of prioritization by maintainers.
Incentivize open-source projects to close vulnerabilities.
marketing: Encourage ethical hacking and reporting vulnerability rather than sharing as a zero-day to threat actors.
Evangelize security education as part of computer science, information systems, and related academic programs.
Leverage DevRel at industry events (speaking, booths) where roles go to learn.
